Award.AwardTitle: Planning for a Teacher Fellowship/Master Teacher Fellowship Program to Serve High-Need Schools in Urban Southwestern Connecticut

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
University of Bridgeport (UB), in partnership with neighboring high-need school districts (Bridgeport, Norwalk, and Stamford) proposes to engage in a highly effective Capacity Building Project leading to the design of a combined Teaching Fellowship/Master Teaching Fellowship (TF/MTF) program. The investigators are developing a program to recruit, prepare, and retain secondary science teachers committed to teaching physical science in high-need school districts in urban Southwestern Connecticut. The project is developing the capacity to recruit ten TFs from UB's student body preparing to graduate in science-related and five MTFs from in-service secondary science teachers who already serve in partner school districts.

The project supports the advancement of discovery through the identification of effective ways of recruiting, preparing, and retaining high-school science teachers in urban high-poverty settings, ultimately leading to enriched and effective learning experiences of underrepresented students in science, and their consequent increased recruitment into science-related careers. In addition, the project is providing essential information for practitioners and scholars by analyzing the practices of expert science teachers who are successful in high-poverty urban school districts, and making their images public (presentation at national conferences and publication in peer-reviewed journals). Third, the benefits of the project to society consist in the potential applications of these findings at a larger scale. As such, it serves as a model of science education improvement in high-need schools for adoption by other teacher preparation institutions nationwide.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In Southwestern Connecticut, the percentages of students considered at goal and proficient in secondary science are well below the state average. This has impacted the state’s workforce quality, resulting in negative consequences for Connecticut’s economy and competitiveness. In consequence, University of Bridgeport (UB) received NSF funds from January 1, 2014 to December 31, 2015 for a Capacity Building project focusing on the design of a combined Teaching Fellowship/Master Teaching Fellowship (TF/MTF) program. This program will be designed to improve the current situation pertaining to the recruitment, preparation and retention of physical science teachers in high-need school districts in urban Southwestern Connecticut.

Throughout the duration of the funding period, our team engaged in conversations with local science teachers and administrators, who provided important suggestions and ideas. These will be included in the design of a new framework intended to increase the recruitment, retention, and support of secondary physical science teachers. Particular attention will be given to recruiting individuals from underrepresented minorities who commit to teaching in high-need schools. First. we plan to create an Education Track available to all science and engineering students from University of Bridgeport, and we expect that some of these students will later be recruited as TFs in the Master’s program in the School of Education. Second, our team established a solid partnership with STEMteachersNYC, an organization founded in 2011 by a group of teachers as a teacher-led physics study group. STEMteachersNYC is affiliated with the American Modeling Teachers Association (AMTA)  and is devoted to excellence in science teaching with a general focus on modeling instruction and inquiry-based teaching. Our team has already organized such workshops at the University of Bridgeport and we will continue to engage local science teachers in similar inquiry-based professional workshops, which will promote the formation of a network that connects science teachers in Connecticut. This network will promote the exchange of instructional ideas and materials among participating teachers, while helping us identify dedicated teacher leaders that can become MTFs in our future program.  

Our team has also identified the resources, constraints, and effective approaches to training science teachers in order to better understand and replicate successful science instruction in urban settings.  One important innovation consists in the identification of undergraduate science and engineering students who had worked with successful teachers during their secondary education. These students have a foundation of what good teaching should look like and will be encouraged to enter the teacher preparation program. This will lead to the formation of motivated science teachers with the necessary background necessary to be successful in the classroom. Additionally, the teacher preparation program at the Master’s level will be complemented by the creation of internship programs for science and engineering undergraduate students. This program will serve as a tool to actively engage these students in teaching and help them decide whether teaching is the right profession for them.
